reason.tex:
%text When $A$ and $B$ say different things, you want to know which of them is \underline{\text{more likely}} to be speaking the truth.
Which means, event C (contradiction) has already occurred. Therefore, the probabilities that you should want to find are
% \begin{tabular}{|c|c|} \hline & \text{Meaning} \\ \hline P(A\,\vert\,C) & \text{A speaking truth given contradiction} \\ \hline P(B\,\vert\,C) & \text{B speaking truth given contradiction} \\ \hline \end{tabular} \\ %text Moreover, you also want to know whether $P(A\vert C)\gt P(B\vert C)$ or $P(B\vert C)\gt P(A\vert C)$. %

%text First, know what $P(C\vert A)$ and $P(C\vert B)$ mean.
% \begin{tabular}{|c|l|} \hline \text{Probability} & \text{Meaning} \\ \hline P(C\vert B) & \text{Contradiction occuring given}\\ &\text{that B is speaking the truth} \\ \hline P(C\vert A) & \text{Contradiction occuring given}\\ &\text{that A is speaking the truth} \\ \hline \end{tabular} \\ %text If $A$ is speaking the truth then $B$ must lie for contradiction $C$ to occur.
Similarly, if $B$ is speaking the truth then $A$ must lie for $C$ to occur.
Mathemtically therefore, % \begin{align} P(C\vert A) &= P(\bar{B}) \\ P(C\vert B) &= P(\bar{A}) \end{align}

options.tex: \begin{align} P(A\vert C) &= \dfrac{P(C\vert A)\cdot P(A)}{P(C)} = \dfrac{P(\bar{B})\cdot P(A)}{P(C)} \\ &= \dfrac{\left(\frac{1}{10}\cdot\frac{6}{10}\right)}{\frac{42}{100}} = \dfrac{1}{7} \\ P(B\vert C) &= \dfrac{P(C\vert B)\cdot P(B)}{P(C)} = \dfrac{P(\bar{A})\cdot P(B)}{P(C)} \\ &= \dfrac{\left( \frac{4}{10}\cdot\frac{9}{10}\right)}{\frac{42}{100}} = \dfrac{6}{7} \end{align} \\ %text $P(B\vert C)\gt P(A\vert C)\implies B$ is more believable than $A$ in case of a contradiction. %

reason.tex: %text We estbalished in Step 4 that we need to compare $P(A\vert C)$ and $P(B\vert C)$. Now, it so happens that % \begin{align} P(A\vert C) &= \dfrac{P(C\vert A)\cdot P(A)}{P(C)} \\ \text{and }P(B\vert C) &=\underbrace{ \dfrac{P(C\vert B)\cdot P(B)}{P(C)}}_{\text{Bayes' Theorem}} \end{align} \\ \text{Moreover, we also know from Step 3 that}\\ \begin{align} P(C\vert A) &= P(\bar{B}) \\ P(C\vert B) &= P(\bar{A}) \end{align} \\ %text Hence, simply plug-in the values and find $P(A\vert C)$ and $P(B\vert C)$. On comparing, you will find that $B$ is more believable. %
